newsitem.title: JAPAN: IBJ cuts long-term prime to 3.0 pct from 3.3 pct.
newsitem.headline: IBJ cuts long-term prime to 3.0 pct from 3.3 pct.

text.p: The Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd said on Monday it will cut its long-term prime rate to three percent from 3.3 percent, effective September 11.
The cut in the prime rate reflects a recent fall in the yield of five-year bank debentures. The prime is what banks charge to their best customers for loans of over one year.
Long-term banks customarily set their long-term prime rate 0.9 percentage point above that of the debenture coupon rate.
The latest IBJ debentures, which have a 2.4 percent coupon, were issued in August and last traded at 2.120 percent on Friday.
The other two long-term banks, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd (LTCB) and Nippon Credit Bank (NCB), are expected to follow suit on Tuesday.
The cut in the long-term prime is the first since June.
